triples.name: Collective motion
triples.relevance: The paper studies how collective motion emerges in locust swarms, extending understanding beyond traditional self-propelled particle models.

triples.name: Self-propelled particles
triples.relevance: The paper uses and ultimately challenges traditional self-propelled particle models that fail to explain locust collective behavior.

triples.name: Desert locust
triples.relevance: Desert locusts are the primary experimental subject and organism studied in this research on collective behavior.

triples.name: Virtual reality
triples.relevance: Virtual reality was used as an experimental tool alongside field and laboratory experiments to test locust behavior.

triples.name: Optomotor response
triples.relevance: The optomotor response is the innate behavior mechanism used by locusts to respond to visual motion stimuli.

triples.name: Consensus dynamics
triples.relevance: The paper proposes consensus dynamics as a key internal mechanism explaining how locusts make collective directional choices.

triples.name: Emergence
triples.relevance: The paper challenges traditional beliefs about how emergence of order arises from disorder in animal collectives.

triples.name: Collective animal behavior
triples.relevance: Understanding collective animal behavior is the core task addressed by studying the behavioral mechanisms in marching locust swarms.
